Even when life is interrupted by a global pandemic, life is still happening. We still have homes to run, we still have to find things we need. We're trying to keep our families together, yet safely apart and we're trying to keep our kids learning when their school buildings stand silent. In this brief conversation, we'll explore what keeps us together as parents and educators and discuss what we have to guard against from ripping us apart. We're not necessarily experiencing it like everyone else. But one thing is for certain; we're all experiencing it. We're living through the same storm, but experiencing it in a different boat.

Dear Parents,

Bosqueville ISD wants to recognize and celebrate the hard work and accomplishments of our 8th-grade students. Due to the global COVID-19 pandemic and guidelines established by national, state, and local health officials, the promotion ceremony will be different for this year's 8th graders. We are creating a slideshow that will showcase each student free of charge and will be made available for viewing later in May.
We encourage everyone's participation as follows:

Students - please submit a 5 - 8-second video of you walking across a (school appropriate) stage of your choosing. Be creative and have fun with this!

Parents - please submit one (1) baby/toddler picture and one (1) current picture of your soon-to-be high schooler.

In summary, we need 2 pictures and a short video for each student. All submissions should be sent to jenny.mcnamara@bosquevilleisd.org no later than Wednesday, May 13th. Please include your child's name with your submission. You may also contact Mrs. McNamara at the previously mentioned email address if you have any questions.

"Classroom Behavior Insights" - Student behavior in a middle school classroom is the result of developmental growth. At this age, students are impulsive, searching for and testing "boundaries" of those they know, seeking adult acceptance while experimenting with independence from adults, and because of brain growth spurts, they cannot sufficiently edit thoughts, things they say, and things they do.

As educators, we know these developmental issues and respond to negative student behavior in ways that communicate that the teacher is in control and there are parameters for acceptable behavior. These parameters ensure a safe, positive, supportive classroom where learning can occur.

The level of success a student experiences during a school year is definitely enhanced by communication and cooperation between parents and teachers. Please feel free to contact your child's instructor or principal.
